text:
Mares Depers Anger at the world makes us intractable and bitter. 
Recently I came across a poem by Omar Sakr: “How are we to walk in a world which is burning?” It seemed apt, because that’s exactly what the modern world feels like, doesn’t it? Glad Group Supervising manager Paul Davidson has a face off with union organiser Rakchanok Sothanaphaisan during a protest over salary negotiations. (Pic: John Appleyard) 
Recently I came across a poem by Omar Sakr: “How are we to walk in a world which is burning?” It seemed apt, because that’s exactly what the modern world feels like, doesn’t it? 
And I’m not talking about the last heatwave or climate change, although the metaphor may be just as relevant in that discussion, I’m talking about the vein-throbbing, tense, red-hot reality of turning on the news or opening social media. Of arguments and division, of headshaking, jaw-clenching, meal-spitting anger. 
Because let’s face it, irrespective of what side of the fence, or ahem wall, you’re on, tensions now run higher than ever. 
Don’t get me wrong, I’m not about to pretend to be a picture of pristine calmness, I mean, I’m angry a lot of the time. On the face of it, I think anger is a perfectly understandable and justifiable response to what is occurring around us daily. 
But understandable and justifiable aren’t the same as effective — just ask anyone whose frustration has led them to break the very thing they were trying to fix. Donald Trump’s Muslim ban caused a mass outpouring of anger, and action, such as this demonstration at Chicago’s O’Hare Airport, but it’s important not to allow anger to cancel out empathy. (Pic: AFP/Joshua Lott) 
Beyond my own struggles I also happen to know a little bit about anger — angry people walk into my office every single day. I never have to look hard to see the collateral damage of overwhelming and crippling stress, broken relationships, blunted communication and emotional hurt which trails behind them. In most cases the anger is a secondary emotion, the outward, observable expression of some other usually much deeper, emotion — sadness, hurt, fear, or uncertainty. Other Stories
